SENT.plain: In a retrospective survey of 66 cases (46 proven) of cerebral venous thrombosis in a large number of public teaching hospitals in Australia, the quantity of cases in institutions of similar size varied widely
There were 29 fatal cases (all underwent an autopsy) and in 20 of these the venous thrombosis was considered to be the major cause of death
In 15 of the deaths due to cerebral venous thrombosis the diagnosis was not suspected before death
In 27 cases (18 proven) the underlying cause was infection, while only two cases (both confirmed) were associated with oral contraceptives
These findings suggest that although rare, cerebral venous thrombosis is underdiagnosed and that, even in the era of modern antibiotics, sepsis is the commonest single identifiable cause
